Fellow, Linacre College

LayoutNode.Content: Wolfson Building, Parks Road, Oxford OX1 3QD
LayoutNode.SRC: Wolfson Building, Parks Road, Oxford OX1 3QD

LayoutNode.Content: I want to understand intelligence and how minds work. My research is multi-disciplinary and focuses primarily on the following areas:
LayoutNode.SRC: I want to understand intelligence and how minds work. My research is multi-disciplinary and focuses primarily on the following areas:

LayoutNode.Content: Machine learning, big data, and computational statistics
LayoutNode.SRC: <LI>Machine learning, big data, and computational statistics

LayoutNode.Content: Artificial intelligence, probabilistic reasoning, and decision making
LayoutNode.SRC: <LI>Artificial intelligence, probabilistic reasoning, and decision making

LayoutNode.Content: Computational neuroscience, neural networks, and cognitive science
LayoutNode.SRC: <LI>Computational neuroscience, neural networks, and cognitive science

LayoutNode.Content: Randomized algorithms, and Monte Carlo simulation

I am a Professor of Computer Science at the University of Oxford. I was previously a full professor in machine learning and artificial intelligence at the department of computer science of the University of British Columbia. There, I was also an adjunct professor of statistics, and cognitive systems. I received my PhD from Trinity College, Cambridge University in 2000 on Bayesian methods for neural networks. From 1999 to 2001, I was a postdoctoral fellow at UC Berkeley in the artificial intelligence group of Stuart Russell. I am a fellow of the Canadian Institute For Advanced Research (CIFAR) in the successful Neural Computation and Adaptive Perception program. I am an occasional entrepreneur: Zite, a big-data spin-off from my previous lab, has won numerous awards and was sold to CNN in 2011. Among my recent awards are a Distinguished Paper Award at the International Joint Conference on Artificial intelligence (IJCAI 2013), the 2012 Charles A. McDowell Award for Excellence in Research, and the 2010 Mathematics of Information Technology and Complex Systems (MITACS) Young Researcher Award.

LayoutNode.Content: Amazon, Facebook, Google and Microsoft support machine learning research at Oxford CS.

LayoutNode.Content: Nando de Freitas receives Google Faculty Research Award for his work on deep learning
LayoutNode.SRC: Nando de Freitas receives Google Faculty Research Award for his work on deep learning

LayoutNode.Content: Recent work on scaling deep networks has led to the construction of the largest artificial neural networks to date, with billions of parameters distributed over several machines. These models are the state-of-the-art in image and speech recognition. It is conjectured that bigger models will result in great improvements in speech, language, vision and other tasks. Scaling up the models is however a difficult challenge, which Nando and his student Misha Denil have undertaken with some recent success.
LayoutNode.SRC: Recent work on scaling deep networks has led to the construction of the largest artificial neural networks to date, with billions of parameters distributed over several machines. These models are the state-of-the-art in image and speech recognition. It is conjectured that bigger models will result in great improvements in speech, language, vision and other tasks. Scaling up the models is however a difficult challenge, which Nando and his student Misha Denil have undertaken with some recent success.
